content: I've just created the agenda for next week https://hackmd.io/KZa0E7ltRASGRFZrx67szw?both
Damn it, I wanted to beat you to that race when you posted the link in #t-compiler/meetings :race:
ouch :), sorry :)

I'll start now having a look at the agenda and fill some holes. My goal is to reduce the time needed to @**Santiago Pastorino** when later today and tomorrow he's gonna finish up and refine it.
How the agenda is prepared is detailed in the Rust Forge knowledge base. Santiago drafted this week's agenda at the end of last week's meeting.

In particular, I'll do:

  • Summarize and update details about nominated issues, regressions, PR waiting for a team feedback (goal: have the compiler team get a understanding at a glance of those issues context)
  • Add the "Performace logs" section (goal: inform the compiler team of the current testing and bulding situation, gather feedbacks)
  • Add the WG-checkins (goal: add WG teams reports and progress statuses, if any)

This is an iterative task that will be finished tomorrow just before the meeting (updates flow in until the last minute)
(HackMD allows seeing previous revisions of the document, handy to check changes)
hey! what's the process nowadays to raise an rfc for the compiler team to look at during their meeting?
namely, the stack probes question in https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2959, I think that's the last holdup of it
I will link that at the top of the "Announcement" section of compiler meeting agenda, should be enough to catch their eyes and trigger a discussion. Feel free to later add details to that!
@Pietro Albini I will also link this issue, seems relevant
:thumbs_up:
@apiraino https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/73908 is not really relevant though
the state of aarch64 linux is different than aarch64 windows or aarch64 macos
didnt read close enough, sorry.
@Pietro Albini We don't raise rfcs. I guess you could convert that rfc into a mcp
@DPC hmm, what's the best way to get the compiler team's opinion on a possible blocker on an RFC?
a MCP seems... weird
maybe @Santiago Pastorino could add this rfc to the agenda

DPC said:

maybe Santiago Pastorino could add this rfc to the agenda

yup, it's there now :smile: Santiago will check if it's the right "place" (I think the intent is just to allocate a brief discussion about that)
ok @Santiago Pastorino I have updated a bit the agenda and we have briefly discussed some of the issues pending prioritization, ended with 2 (as of now) still undecided
@Pietro Albini @DPC @apiraino I usually add this kind of stuff to the Nominated section, before the nominated issues
we may want to rename that section of the agenda to something like Up for discussion
but with the given structure of the agenda, the right thing is to add whatever we want to discuss in the nominations section

Santiago Pastorino said:

we may want to rename that section of the agenda to something like Up for discussion

I'm partially in favor of keeping the current name ("Nominated issues") as changing that single word would imply other cascading changes (ex. the documentation) for (imho) not great gain
Do we have a calendar that is easy to download?
(a meeting calendar that is)
Here you can find an ICS file or import using Google Calendar
we don't have meetings any more :smile:
we used to have when we formed, but realised that it's better if most of the work is done async-ly and kept the meeting slot only to discuss if anything comes up (haven't had to in a month yet)
when we refer to agenda - we refer to the compiler team's meeting which happens every Thursday at 14.00 UTC in #t-compiler/meetings
this https://forge.rust-lang.org/compiler/prioritization/procedure.html#follow-ups-from-previous-meeting was done right after last meeting
checking https://forge.rust-lang.org/compiler/prioritization/procedure.html#prepare-agenda-content
#76733
#76679
are missing T-compiler
adding it
going to fix all those urls on the procedure because we can filter out all the teams
PR is up forge#440
anyway, that's just to improve a bit the procedure
next
https://forge.rust-lang.org/compiler/prioritization/procedure.html#assign-priority-to-unprioritized-issues-with-i-prioritize-label

there are 3 issues pending prioritization as we can see https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3AT-compiler+-label%3AP-critical+-label%3AP-high+-label%3AP-medium+-label%3AP-low+label%3AI-prioritize
going to switch to #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and check all the issues since last time as a way to review a bit and to assign priorities to these 3, this is going to take some time :)
will be back in this stream in a bit
gonna continue here, sorry because I got distracted with other stuff
after that comes
https://forge.rust-lang.org/compiler/prioritization/procedure.html#accept-mcps
nothing to do there
next
https://forge.rust-lang.org/compiler/prioritization/procedure.html#run-cli-to-generate-agenda
also created a PR to fix the command which was changed since a while
forge#441
have changed some little parts of the agenda to start
https://forge.rust-lang.org/compiler/prioritization/procedure.html#remove-to-announce-from-mcpsfcps
done that, I'd need to fix the FFCPs https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?q=is%3Aall+label%3Afinished-final-comment-period+label%3Ato-announce
there are things that are not T-compiler we would need to check if those are of T-compiler's interest
will do in a bit
next
https://forge.rust-lang.org/compiler/prioritization/procedure.html#fill-agenda-announcements
adding things from the compiler calendar
in particular Compiler team MCP retrospective
https://forge.rust-lang.org/compiler/prioritization/procedure.html#fill-agenda-announcements
was filled already, probably by @apiraino :)
https://forge.rust-lang.org/compiler/prioritization/procedure.html#notify-the-team-about-the-meeting

Santiago Pastorino said:

https://forge.rust-lang.org/compiler/prioritization/procedure.html#notify-the-team-about-the-meeting

Notifications to teams end up here, in the T-compiler weekly meeting message
https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/238009-t-compiler.2Fmeetings/topic/.5Bweekly.20meeting.5D.202020-09-17.20.2354818
@apiraino thanks for the remainder :), I was going to mention exactly that
have just done it there :)
the last part now is to review the agenda and to complete https://forge.rust-lang.org/compiler/prioritization/procedure.html#add-details-to-the-agenda
all the sections there, basically the summarization of issues in the agenda
going over that right now
ohh before that, I forgot
the FFCPs
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?q=is%3Aall+label%3Afinished-final-comment-period+label%3Ato-announce
That is a really interesting workflow
say more :)
please always keep an eye on things to improve and do not hesitate to mention what we could make better
there are parts of the procedure that are done by people that know the process so it may not be clear to others

Stu said:

That is a really interesting workflow

I'm always amazed by the Rust project, there's impressive work, with huge quality standards, automations, and collaboration even to build a meeting agenda ;)
Yea that's what amazes me about the internals of rust development.
if you think the ton of stuff that happens behind the scenes to have an agenda for a meeting is amazing :)
Thanks for running through all that in detail. It really helped to see the whole workflow demonstrated from start to finish!
great if it helps more or less
I know it's hard because you see me commenting that I start and then that I have done X but you don't see me doing that stuff :)

Santiago Pastorino said:

Stu said:

That is a really interesting workflow

I'm always amazed by the Rust project, there's impressive work, with huge quality standards, automations, and collaboration even to build a meeting agenda ;)

the thing that impressed me most was rust-lang/teams
you don't have to worry about permissions or getting set up or anything
right, even that
you just make a PR and it happens
yeah, this is exactly what I meant
thats crazy

teams is a bit sketchy in few places, but yeah it's an improvement compared to the earlier process (sometimes i wonder how i have more permissions which some people who deserve them, dont :grinning: )
@WG-prioritization in particular new members #76466 neesds bisection
cargo-bisect-rustc would be a nice tool to try out
you can create that project
and call cargo-bisect-rustc even without parameters and wait for a result :), that simple
but possibly it's an LLVM regression
and last ... the agenda is ready, it would be nice to read it and check it out if looks good

Santiago Pastorino said:

but possibly it's an LLVM regression

worth noticing the issue reporter ran into that issues on a Win10
Agenda looks great! Tomorrow we will give some retouch with last minute small changes (if any)

apiraino said:

Santiago Pastorino said:

but possibly it's an LLVM regression

worth noticing the issue reporter ran into that issues on a Win10

please feel free to add this info
agreed, it's important
OK, the compiler meeting has ended and @**Santiago Pastorino** has already prepared the draft for the next one, scheduled for Sept. 24th, here's is the agenda draft
from now until next Wed/Thu we will monitor the issues that are requested a prioritization and asynchronously act just like we did in the past few days
thanks also to new members that contributed insights to assign a priority

Just a FIY that all compiler team meetings are public and can be retrieved at any time also from this Zulip instance static storage
https://zulip-archive.rust-lang.org/238009tcompilermeetings/index.html
another thought now that we are a lot of people in the group, one of the things that need better care is the summarization
I meant, after we write down an issue on the agenda, it is nice to try to understand it properly, to sanity check it and then try to fill an explanation as a summary
things that we should check, if the issue says nightly regression, we can check if it's really a nightly regression or that has already hit beta
because once we fork a new beta, I don't think there are automations to change the labels to all issues so a lot of issues end with wrongs labels
and I keep checking issues for update until right before the meeting
from time to time we have summaries and then a comment with a patch shows up and if we do not update at the point of the meeting most of the summaries do not make sense
and things like that :)
the prioritization part of the work seems to be working great and even more now that there's a lot of people helping out :heart:
Okay. So we should just check if all summaries, regressions, etc are correct before the meeting?
we should provide the summaries
but I meant, from time to time we fill some stuff and gets outdated and things like that
and also the issues may have been labelled since a while and the state of things may have changed
I guess one way to explain this better is by explaining it more generally
imagine this situation
we are adding a P-critical issue to be discussed during the compiler team meeting
members of the compiler team are going to read our summaries and then join the issue
if there are things that do not make sense, we or the issue will be misleading the discussion
the team is going to figure all that out of course but it will take time and the team is going to be able to discuss less stuff
Ah okay. That makes sense. Thank you
the release team normally checks the regressions before cutting a new beta fwiw
@DPC good to know, but it may be just that things are incorrectly tagged, unsure
let me find an example from today
@DPC #76803
that one was clearly incorrectly labelled as nightly regression
but yeah, what I meant is ... in general this are the kind of things we need to check
if labels are correct
among other things
